meta_data.title: Do the Old Testament “Rape Laws” Oppress Women?

interpreted it as well. So is it possible that a woman is being forced to marry her rapist?
Technically with the language that is a possible interpretation or translation,
but it's not the only one. And in my opinion, it's not the best one. Not likely. Yeah. Yeah. And it
doesn't, and again, it doesn't fit with a lot of the other stuff. It doesn't feel the rest of that,
even that passage. Right. So which is really helpful. There you go. That's a lot I know,
but no, it's good, though. I think that's helpful. Yeah. Because if it, if it was strongly, clearly
encouraging that, that would have a lot of implications. Yeah. You know,
great. Are we ready to move towards the New Testament?
So then transitioning into the New Testament, which as we said in the beginning, I think.
In the beginning is in the Old Testament. In the, no, sorry. In the beginning was the word.
In the beginning of this little shots fired. He's exactly right. It's in the New Testament.
But yeah, so now, so we're moving by the way, if you have questions about the Hebrew laws or
whatever, send them in. We'll cover any of the ones that you want to have covered. Yeah.
That'll be good. Carry on. No, I was saying, as we said at the beginning of this conversation,
specifically, the, a lot of the understanding of this when it comes to a bigger picture is seeing
how Jesus specifically, the laws that he brings up again and the things that he emphasizes, because
like we talked about before, a lot of the Old Testament has been fulfilled or was specific
to Jewish culture. And so to, to figure out what Jesus thinks and what God's standards are for us
today, a lot of that takes us looking at what Jesus taught. And so that's what we were going
to move into. And then just into kind of the New Testament when it comes to women specifically.
And so I think it's helpful to start, like we said before, with the culture that Jesus
was born into the Jewish Greek and Roman culture all did not treat women particularly well.
Right. And so, and so just starting with that, and then understanding that Jesus was very
countercultural in many, many ways with how he lived and what he taught. And so,
and I think it's cool just seeing kind of as an overview of the way that Jesus did teach on these
things, but also just the way that he interacted without even having to say anything, spoke volumes
about his view of women, because it was viewed as shocking and is recorded as shocking to his
disciples and the Pharisees and Sadducees. And not just his interaction with women in general,
or upstanding women, but scandalous women, who would have tainted his reputation as a
religious teacher. Did taint his reputation. Yeah, absolutely. Just by being around them
and associating with them, correct? His was not chasing them off or yeah. Yeah. And traveling
with them and speaking with them. And so there are so many examples. I don't know if we want to
go into specifics, but pick a couple. Yeah. A couple of favorites. Yeah. I think, I think
this American woman is a really common one, but I think breaking it down is helpful because
understanding that there are so many layers of, of just kind of the forbidden nature of
that woman or the outcast nature of that woman when it comes to just the Samaritans in general,
being a people that a lot of the Jews viewed as outcast because they had been Jewish people that
had married with non-Jewish people and they would not even walk through their town culturally,
because they didn't want to associate with them. And so Jesus from the beginning walks through
right. Right. And then this woman, so not only is she Samaritan, but she's an outcast even in
Samaria. And so she is outcast even among her own people because of the way that she has lived. And
Jesus takes time out of his, I mean, you imagine all the people in this area and then he takes
time to go to Samaria. And then of all the people in Samaria, it takes time to speak to this one
woman and speaks with her alone, which is also scandalous, but just takes time to show her value
and speak to her story and tell her, I know your story and know who you are and give her hope is
phenomenal. Like it's, it's amazing. But when his disciples come back and see him speaking with her,
they're like, what are you doing? Right. Yeah. They apparently stand there awkwardly while he finishes
this conversation with her. Yeah. But keep in mind, we just read the Deuteronomy laws. He's not in
the city. Right. And he's talking to a woman who is with a man. I mean, this could get him killed.
Right. If she accuses him of rape, he could be executed for it. Now, it's a Samaria. I don't
know if Samaria was at that time following the Deuteronomy laws or not. I don't know if anyone
knows because they had their own temple and their own sacrifices and kind of their own laws, but
I don't know if they're following those or not, but this just shows you what Jesus was willing to do
in order to help redeem this woman. From a Jewish perspective, you'd be like,
regardless of where we are, this could be bad for you. Oh yeah. So that's interesting.
So that's one that stands out. I don't know if there's any other part of that story that
I'm missing, but just, you see that throughout the whole life of, or the whole ministry of Jesus,
is him taking time to spend with or heal or invite, you know, even women who traveled with him,
women who, A, they were women, and then B, sometimes they weren't even women that were
culturally respected at all. And he communicates value to them and takes time to teach them as
well as men, which, you know, even his conversation with Mary, he allows her, you know, Martha's up
serving and rushing around. And Mary Martha, the sisters, and he even praises Mary for taking time
away from working and serving him, like Martha is, just because she wants to sit at his feet and
learn from him. And instead of saying like, what are you doing? This is for the men. Like, go,
go serve. And just like the kindness that he interacts with women over and over again is very
countercultural. And I think we miss that often because of the culture that we're in. It doesn't
stand out to us unless we stop to think about it. Right. It's fascinating that we never see him join
anyone in sin. And yet he is willing to engage with what his culture would have considered
sinners with dignity, which is the Christian ethic, the Judeo-Christian ethic, but a lot of
people weren't doing that then. So whether it's the Phoenician woman... A lot of us aren't doing it
very well now. Right, exactly. So the Phoenician woman who asks for healing, or the woman who
breaks the vase or breaks the jar of nard over him. And I mean, some of these are scandalous
interactions in the culture. I mean, the Pharisees he's having dinner with are freaking out.
Probably would have stood up and screamed and yelled when the woman started washing his feet
with her tears. And yet Jesus accepts this as an act of worship and preparation for his burial.
Isn't it fascinating that women get to prepare him for the burial and then the women are the ones
who come to prepare his body only to discover that he's been raised. Right. Like even the
dignity that women are given as witnesses. Yeah, that was my other favorite one. Oh, yeah. No,
no, keep going. It's just wild that the Christian New Testament treats women as very much so
equal in value, equal in significance, equal in importance to the men. The Gospels are
big about that. And I don't... It's always wild to me that you have
he... Even the lineage of Jesus emphasizes women either... It emphasizes a handful of women
who are not either not Jewish or who are questionable in their reputation. And those are
just... They're not hidden. They're not... They're emphasized. And it's just, it's crazy to consider
if someone was inventing a religion, you would never, never, never do that. You would never put
these women in his lineage. You would never tell their stories. You would never make them
significant. You never make them the first witnesses to Jesus's resurrection. Exactly.
Because they wouldn't have been... Women weren't taken as a reputable witness in court, right?
Right, right. And so if you were... Yeah, like you're saying, if you were just creating this
or fabricating it, you never would have had women be the first ones to see him be raised.
Yeah, they go back and get the men and the men... The men go back to go check it out,
but they're even more confused. I mean, the women really are the ones who saw him.
And seem to believe quicker than the men. Oh yeah. Yeah, Mary Magdalene, the one from Magdala,
she's very much so the first. Though at some point, a pope decided she was a prostitute. That's
actually not in the Bible. Interesting. But she was demon possessed at one point. And so
it's, again, a fascinating interaction there that that's who he's got. But keep in mind,
when he goes home to Nazareth, that the people of Nazareth refer to him as the son of Joseph.
So apparently they didn't buy Mary's whole conceived by the Holy Spirit story back home.
And so Mary would have been a woman of ill repute probably her whole life as well.
If the people didn't buy Joseph and Mary's story, then they would have assumed, well,
it's probably Joseph's kid. And so I know they're telling this whole, the angel came story like
wink, wink, nudge, nudge, and angel showed up and conceived by the Holy Spirit. But yeah, Mary
probably lived her whole life under the shadow of that scandal. Some people have said that's
probably why there was quote, no room for her at the end. There's no, that's all, we now know
that's all apocryphally wrong. There was, there was no space for her in the guest room. It may be more
to do with their reputation than anything else. Is that like, no, gosh, we just assume you not give
birth to the child that you conceived out of wedlock here in our home. And so we really don't
know the details there, but I mean, Jesus may have been raised by a woman who, whose reputation
was tough. So pretty rough. But yeah, you see that very clearly in Jesus's work. He doesn't overturn
the gender roles. He doesn't overturn the status quo of all of that. He just within the cultural
context, he treats everybody with dignity and compassion, which again, gives us our example.
That's pretty cool. And also just as a side note, I think it's a great conviction for believers,
because often it seems for all of time have had a confusion between engaging in sin and loving
others who are living differently than we are. And I don't like saying loving the center because
we're all centers, but right. But wanting and even when it comes to like different demographics or
social status, like we're terrible as humans about wanting to be associated with people who
somehow are viewed as an outcast by our little subculture. And every subculture has groups that
are not cool to hang out with. And we often associate it is for some reason still so hard
for believers to understand the difference between, you know, condoning sin and engaging
in it and loving other people well and engaging with them. That's right. Like not just holding
them in an arm's length. And I think this is a great example of that. But anyway, and it's part
of why modern identity politics, while it's a fascinating thing to learn about and to understand
the history of and to see how that stuff plays into things, it's never going to integrate well
with Christianity that our fundamental identity is found in our ethnicity or is found in our social
status or is found in our whatever, because Jesus transitioned between those so easily interacting
with people who were culturally the top, the very, very top of the heap, the Pharisees, the Sanhedrin.
And he has no problem with them. I mean, he engages with, oh, all of a sudden, again, my brain, who's
who's he talking to in John three? Nicodemus. Thank you. Right. Good old Nicodemus. Yeah,
Nicodemus, who is probably a wealthy, top ranking Pharisee. And, and before and after is talking
with, you know, the woman at the weather that so these people who he's interacting with, he,
his identity is not found in ethnicity or socio it's found in the fact that all humans are,
yeah, all humans are creating the image of God and are worthy of being treated with dignity and
respect. And so he does. And that doesn't mean that those differentiations aren't there don't
matter. It just means that everyone's equal regardless. Yeah. In that sense, they're all
the same. And so it's fascinating to see him do that for us so well and model that for us.
But we're running out of time here and we need to get to there's a new numbers of number of places,
numerous places, I'm trying to say both those words at the same time, numberous places.
Where, where Paul talks about cultural context when it comes to the role of women and the role
of women in church and things like that. We probably ought to talk about those if we're
gonna talk about that. That's great. That next time. Yeah. And if you have any questions regarding
these specific things, or things that are just have been hiccups for you that we haven't covered
yet, please send us an email. Let us know. And thanks for listening. We really appreciate it.
Thank you for joining us for this episode of reconstructed faith. If you enjoyed what you
heard or were challenged, please leave us a review. It'll help other people to find us.
If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed,
shoot me an email at info at southspring.org.
Reconstructed faith is a resource of South Spring Baptist Church.
Remember, don't give up. Trust God. Search for answers.
